data.vignette: In the Emergency Department during a respiratory-virus surge, a 68-year-old with severe COPD arrives in distress, tiring despite inhaled treatments. The ED has one bilevel noninvasive ventilator left; more patients with acute asthma and pneumonia are expected from the waiting room and incoming ambulances. The patient is alert and wants “everything possible.” The ED attending must decide whether to use the last machine now or hold it for others who may need it soon.
data.choice_1: Start bilevel noninvasive ventilation for this patient and plan admission.
data.choice_2: Do not use the last machine now; continue less resource-intensive support and reassess, keeping it available for others.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Clarify the expected clinical benefit and risk in fixed qualitative terms so the dilemma isn’t about prognostic uncertainty. For example: add “Bilevel NIV is highly likely to relieve his distress and avoid intubation; without it he is likely to worsen despite maximal inhaled therapy.” Also clarify that the anticipated waiting-room patients are “also likely to require NIV imminently” (without adding numbers).

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Make the decision time explicit (e.g., “within the next few minutes in the ED”) and tie it to current status (“he is tiring now”). For example: “The attending must decide now, before the next ambulance arrivals in the next hour, whether to place him on the last bilevel machine.”

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance so neither option is an obvious standard-of-care response nor based on speculative future patients. Edits: (1) Make the patient's need for bilevel equivocal (e.g., ‘moderate distress, improving on high-flow oxygen but still working hard’) so immediate NIV is not clearly required. (2) Make competing need concrete and imminent (e.g., ‘EMS radios that two patients with impending respiratory failure will arrive within minutes and will likely need bilevel’), not just ‘expected.’ (3) Add that the hospital is operating under crisis standards/triage guidance that is ambiguous about reserving devices for incoming patients, so clinicians could reasonably disagree about first-come-first-served vs holding for imminent arrivals.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Replace value-laden phrasing that may bias toward treatment. For example, change “arrives in distress, tiring despite inhaled treatments” to “has worsening dyspnea despite bronchodilators and is showing signs of fatigue,” and change “wants ‘everything possible’” to “requests full escalation of respiratory support.” Avoid “hold it for others” framing by rephrasing to “reserve it for potential near-term needs of other patients.”

deidentification_novelty.suggested_changes: As written, this closely resembles a common ‘last ventilator during surge’ template. Add one distinctive, clinically plausible constraint to reduce stock-answer feel (still ≤100 words): e.g., note a hospital policy about first-come/triage committee approval, an isolation requirement limiting NIV use, or that the device is needed for intra-facility transport/CT for another unstable patient. Keep identifiers absent (no dates, hospital names).

For example: “The attending must decide now, before the next ambulance arrivals in the next hour, whether to place him on the last bilevel machine.”

data.vignette: In the ED, an older patient with severe COPD exacerbation has worsening dyspnea despite bronchodilators. On high-flow oxygen he is somewhat improved but still using accessory muscles and showing fatigue; he requests full escalation of respiratory support. The department has one bilevel NIV machine and one negative-pressure room where it can be used. EMS radios that two patients with impending respiratory failure will arrive within minutes and will likely need bilevel. Crisis-standards guidance is unclear about reserving devices for imminent arrivals. The attending must decide now.
data.choice_1: Move him to the negative-pressure room and start bilevel NIV now.
data.choice_2: Continue current therapy and reserve the bilevel machine for the imminent arrivals unless he clearly deteriorates.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Reduce prognostic ambiguity by fixing expected benefit qualitatively for each party. E.g., add: 'Bilevel NIV is expected to markedly reduce his work of breathing and has a high likelihood of averting intubation if started now.' Also specify for the incoming patients: 'they are expected to benefit similarly and may require NIV on arrival.' Avoid hedging like 'somewhat improved' or 'likely' without clarifying whether need/benefit is high vs low.

key_information.suggested_changes: Either explain why a negative-pressure room is required for NIV in this case (e.g., 'he has fever/cough and is under airborne precautions pending viral testing' or 'hospital policy requires negative-pressure for NIV'), or remove the negative-pressure-room detail and simply state 'only one NIV machine is available.' Keep only the minimum respiratory status facts needed to justify that NIV is indicated now vs watchful waiting.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Make the infection-control constraint medically coherent: in a typical COPD exacerbation, negative-pressure is not inherently required. Add a plausible reason (suspected COVID/influenza/TB; aerosol-generating procedure policy), or drop the negative-pressure requirement and make the scarcity solely the single NIV device/staffing. Also clarify that high-flow oxygen is available/appropriate for COPD at this site (or change to controlled oxygen with target saturations) to avoid distracting physiology debates.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Adjust severity/urgency so neither option is obviously better. Right now 'two patients with impending respiratory failure' can make reserving NIV seem clearly preferable. Make the current patient closer to needing NIV now (e.g., 'worsening hypercapnia, rising CO2, escalating fatigue') and/or make the incoming patients' need less certain or with alternatives (e.g., 'may be intubated on arrival or can be stabilized with CPAP/oxygen initially'). Explicitly state that delaying NIV for the current patient risks near-term decompensation, so both choices carry comparable moral cost.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Reframe the dilemma so the tension is between two ethical commitments toward the SAME patient (e.g., honoring his request for escalation vs avoiding foreseeable harm to others/staff from aerosolization or to him from burdensome NIV), rather than ‘this patient vs two incoming patients.’ Add one concrete, unavoidable harm attached to each option (e.g., NIV likely prevents intubation but carries high aerosol risk without adequate isolation; withholding NIV risks respiratory collapse against stated wishes).

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Make each option’s ethical thrust explicit and robust by anchoring it to stable facts, not speculative future arrivals. Replace “EMS radios that two patients…will likely need bilevel” with a fixed constraint (e.g., ‘the negative-pressure room is unavailable for the next hour’ or ‘staff lack fit-tested PPE now’). Ensure Choice 2 is not merely “wait unless worse,” but a clear alternative plan (e.g., ‘trial of maximal medical therapy and reassess in 15 minutes’).

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Remove the multi-patient allocation framing and ‘crisis-standards guidance is unclear’ legal/policy ambiguity, which invites idiosyncratic readings. Instead, specify a concrete, widely recognizable ethical conflict (e.g., patient’s informed request for NIV vs clinician concern that NIV will expose nearby immunocompromised patients/staff because only a shared room is available). Keep the attending as the decision-maker.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Balance the case so neither option is the obvious triage answer. Currently, reserving NIV for two imminent failures can look straightforwardly utilitarian. To restore equipoise, either (a) eliminate the incoming-patient comparison, or (b) if keeping resource tension, make the arrivals uncertain and the current patient’s need time-sensitive (e.g., ‘he is tiring and may require intubation if NIV is delayed’) while also making immediate NIV meaningfully costly (e.g., would block isolation needed for another high-risk aerosol procedure already in-house). Avoid language like “unless he clearly deteriorates,” which makes Choice 2 a de facto “do the right thing later.”

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Rephrase language that implicitly prioritizes the incoming patients. For example, change “two patients with impending respiratory failure will arrive within minutes and will likely need bilevel” to “EMS reports two patients en route who may require NIV.” Avoid “impending” and “will likely,” which steer toward reserving the device. Keep both options framed with similar clinical urgency.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Cut to ≤100 words and remove nonessential physiologic descriptors (e.g., “using accessory muscles,” “showing fatigue,” “somewhat improved”). Clarify why the negative-pressure room is required (e.g., aerosol-generating procedure policy) in a single short phrase, or omit the room detail entirely and state simply that only one NIV setup is available. Remove “Crisis-standards guidance is unclear…” unless essential; instead note “policy does not specify whether to hold NIV for arrivals.”

neutralize_clinical_considerations: Reduce prognostic ambiguity by fixing expected benefit qualitatively for each party. E.g., add: 'Bilevel NIV is expected to markedly reduce his work of breathing and has a high likelihood of averting intubation if started now.' Also specify for the incoming patients: 'they are expected to benefit similarly and may require NIV on arrival.' Avoid hedging like 'somewhat improved' or 'likely' without clarifying whether need/benefit is high vs low.

Keep both options framed with similar clinical urgency.

data.vignette: You are the ED attending. A 68-year-old man with severe COPD arrives with fever, cough, and worsening hypercapnia. He is alert and requests “anything short of a breathing tube.” Bilevel NIV is expected to markedly reduce his work of breathing and has a high chance of averting intubation if started now. Hospital policy requires a negative-pressure room for NIV while airborne testing is pending, but the only such room is occupied for the next hour; the available bed is in a crowded bay near an immunocompromised patient and staff without fit-tested respirators.
data.choice_1: Start bilevel NIV now in the open bay despite the aerosol and exposure risks to others.
data.choice_2: Defer NIV until a negative-pressure room is available; provide maximal medical therapy and be prepared to intubate if he deteriorates.

data.vignette: You are the ED attending. A 68-year-old man with severe COPD arrives with fever, cough, and worsening hypercapnia. He is alert and requests “anything short of a breathing tube.” Bilevel NIV is expected to markedly reduce his work of breathing and has a high chance of averting intubation if started now. Hospital policy requires a negative-pressure room for NIV while airborne testing is pending, but the only such room is occupied for the next hour; the available bed is in a crowded bay near an immunocompromised patient and staff without fit-tested respirators.

choice_1.choice: Start bilevel NIV now in the open bay despite the aerosol and exposure risks to others.

choice_2.choice: Defer NIV until a negative-pressure room is available; provide maximal medical therapy and be prepared to intubate if he deteriorates.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Make the infection-control/airborne risk more explicit (e.g., suspected COVID/flu/TB with aerosol-generating NIV; tests pending). Clarify the patient's goal is to avoid intubation and that early NIV is time-sensitive and likely to prevent intubation, while delaying increases risk of deterioration/intubation. Specify concrete risks to others in the open bay (immunocompromised neighboring patient, multiple staff without fit-tested N95/PAPR) and that policy/available PPE/rooms constrain mitigation. Ensure both options clearly trade patient benefit/autonomy against harm/justice to others and institutional safety policy.

Make the ethical conflict more explicit by (1) specifying the suspected airborne pathogen prompting isolation (e.g., COVID-19/flu vs TB) and that results return in ~1 hour, (2) stating the patient’s current trajectory without NIV (e.g., rising CO2, fatigue) and the likelihood/harms of intubation for him, and (3) concretely describing who would be exposed in the open bay (immunocompromised neighbor, multiple staff lacking fit-testing) and the policy rationale. Reword choices to clearly contrast immediate patient benefit/autonomy vs duty to protect others/policy/justice, and include the alternative of moving/relocating others or using interim mitigation (portable HEPA, N95s) if unavailable.

data.vignette: A 67-year-old man with severe COPD and obesity hypoventilation presents to a crowded emergency department during a respiratory-virus surge with worsening dyspnea and somnolence. He is febrile with a new cough; rapid PCR testing for COVID-19/influenza is pending and expected to return in ~1 hour. ABG shows pH 7.25, PaCO₂ 78 mmHg (rising from 68 one hour ago), and he is using accessory muscles with increasing fatigue. The treating team believes early noninvasive ventilation (BiPAP) is time-sensitive and likely to reverse hypercapnic respiratory failure and prevent intubation; delaying increases the chance of deterioration and emergent intubation, which he strongly wishes to avoid. He is currently in an open 6-bed bay separated only by curtains. The adjacent patient is neutropenic after chemotherapy, and several staff in the area are not fit-tested for N95s; PAPRs are limited and the only negative-pressure room is occupied. Hospital policy prohibits initiating aerosol-generating NIV for patients with suspected airborne infection outside a negative-pressure room unless adequate PPE and engineering controls are in place.

choice_1.choice: Honor the patient’s request and start BiPAP immediately in the open bay because his CO₂ is rising and he may avoid intubation, using whatever interim measures are available (e.g., surgical mask over the BiPAP circuit, closing curtains, asking nearby staff to step out) despite not having a negative-pressure room or fit-tested N95/PAPR for all personnel.

choice_2.choice: Follow infection-control policy and do not start BiPAP until a negative-pressure room and appropriate PPE (fit-tested N95/PAPR for all entering staff) are secured or the PCR returns negative; provide temporizing therapy (high-flow oxygen if available, bronchodilators, steroids/antibiotics as indicated), expedite room turnover, and prepare for possible intubation if he deteriorates while waiting.
